newsitem.title: UK: Cairn resumes drop amid profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Cairn resumes drop amid profit-taking.

text.p: Shares in Cairn Energy Plc fell to their lowest level in more than three months on Thursday as investors, disappointed that the UK oil exploration concern did not attract a bid, took profits, dealers said.
By 0822 GMT, the stock, down for five straight sessions, had dipped 18-1/2p to 512-1/2.
The stock has been struggling since April 29 when Cairn and Shell Exploration B.V., a unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, announced an alliance.
Under the terms of the agreement, which still need governmental approvals, the companies will combine their oil and gas exploration and production activities in Bangladesh and areas of India.
"There were a lot of people who were hoping that Shell would make a bid for Cairn, but I don't think it was ever in the cards," said one dealer.
Cairn shares had risen sharply from mid-December to mid-March, when they reached an intraday peak of 640. Dealers said the rally was fuelled, at least in part, by bid speculation.
"The deal with Shell is a good one," said another dealer, who says the stock is oversold. "Shell is a big partner and that can only be good news for the company over the long term."
